_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Auto valve, unloading hose, tank cathodic anode.
_prev_prog_3.Description: Only specially trained mechanics are authorized to unload pentane.  The unloading is conducted only during daylight hours.  The unloading site is Federal Railroad Administration approved for unloading n-Pentane including procedures for grounding, emergency fire shut-offs and A.F.F.F. foam suppression system, spill control and capture and emergency brigade response.

_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: Goodwill Fire Co. of Hyde Park

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A)  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

It is CRYOVAC's policy and procedure to operate its facilities in a safe and environmentally responsible way.  It is each facility and/or Division Manager's responsibility to ensure that all Corporate, Division, and regulatory laws, rules, policies, and/or procedures are followed.  It is the responsibility of each employee to adhere to these laws, etc. and to conduct themselves in a safe manner when performing their tasks.

The Sealed Air Corporation has embraced and is committed to the "World Class Manufacturing" program; a portion of this program strives for safety and environmental excellence.  Audits are performed on each facility to ensure that the program is being adhered to and Division managers are responsible to correct any recommended deficiencies of an audit.

The facility has a safety operations program that supports worker and public health, safety, fire security and environmental issues.  The facility has written and published an "Emergency Operations Manual (EOM)" to provide guidance and procedures to follow in an emergency situation for in-house emergency commanders, management staff, and workers.  The manual's format is a "what if" type book that covers all emergencies that are perceived to be able to happen to the facility from security emergencies to chemical spills or leaks.  The facility has also organized, trained, and equipped an in-house emergency brigade covering all shifts and trained/equipped to OSHA 1910.156 regulations for an interior/exterior fire brigade.

Preplans are a part of the EOM and the brigade trains on the plans.  The plans are reviewed annually and the brigade trains quarterly for fire suppression/prevention, annually for confined Space/High Angle Rescue, annually for Hazardous Materials Techician Review (OSHA 1910.120), annually (each shift) for total plant evacuation, and annually for first aid to the ERT American Red Cross level.

N-Pentane delivery, storage, and use has a preplan in the EOM and is

a part of the "Pentane Preplan", which includes the sanitary sewer "Slug Loading Prevention Plan" as required by the City of Reading, PA., Bureau of Water and Sewer.

B)  PROCESS OVERVIEW

CRYOVAC Food Packaging Division is a converter of hard polystyrene resin pellets into soft foam sheet and then into tray type containers for the food industry.  The containers are used primarily as red meat packaging trays, poultry trays, and market ready type containers.  During the initial process, known as extrusion, the pellets are heated under pressure along with colorants and blowing agents in an extruder machine and then discharged as foam around a die and over a mandrel that cools and slices the foam into sheets.  The sheet is rolled on a winder and set to age.  After aging is complete, the roll of sheet is thermoformed by heating the sheet and molding the parts, which are cut out of the sheet and packed for customers.

C)  OVERVIEW OF BLOWING AGENT

One of the blowing agents in foam manufacturing is n-Pentane, which is injected into the extruder barrel at high pressue and at low volume to assist in creating "cells" in the liquified plastic to manufacture foam.  The n-Pentane is pumped through a continuous loop system at relatively low pressue and returned to its underground pump storage tank.  Each extruder machine uses n-Pentane as required, on demand.  In addition to the pump storage tank, there is an additional underground storage tank that is a static (no pumps) tank and is interconnected (piped) to each other.  The n-Pentane is transferred from the static tank to the pump tank via a siphon pipeline.  Each tank holds 19,800 gallons and can only be filled to 90% due to safety interlocks installed in the filling system.  The receiving area, filling system, and tank storage are enclosed by a 10 foot high chain link fence which is inside the facilities 10 foot high and one foot barbed wire perimeter fence that is looked over by a contracted security force.

N-Pentane is d

elivered to the facility by truck tankers that hold up to 9,000 gallons or 47,250 lbs. and is unloaded, by gravity, through a modern tank filling system that includes a diked capture system equal to the capacity of the tanker.  A static grounding system is interlocked with the unloading air valve that stops the unloading action if the ground connection is interrupted.  The capture vault, tanker, unloading station, and the immediate area are protected by an AFFF firefighting foam fixed system that can discharge 2,300 gallons of foam per minute.  On occasion, n-Pentane is received by a rail tanker car of 30,000 gallons or 157,500 lbs. capacity.  The unloading method is essentially the same as for truck tankers.

D)  WORST CASE SCENARIO

The worst case scenario assumes a flammable hydrocarbon vapor cloud detonation from a boiling liquid expanding vapor explosion (BLEVE) of a 30,000 gallon or 157,500 lb. Railroad tanker car.  RMP*Comp A? calculations for this volume of pentane.

The likelihood of an actual BLEVE of the tanker is unlikely due to the multilayered safety devices that have been installed at the unloading rack area.  In addition to passive safety devices, there are safe unloading procedures based on training programs that must be followed for safety management of the product.

E)  ALTERNATE WORST CASE SCENARIO

The more likely incident is a ruptured unloading hose from a highway tanker truck.  As an alternate scenario, the ruptured hose from a "pull away" accident or a horizontal split of the hose casing (due to age) would cause a pool, which could ignite creating a pool fire.  The amount discharged before the source could be shut off would be about 2,050 lbs. a minute for about 5 minutes.  RMP*(Comp A? to calculate the endpoint which may not reach the property boundaries.

The procedures in place, such as the unloaidng mechanic may not leave the vessel unless relieved by an equally trained mechanic, makes the likelihood of a major spill/leak very remote.  P

entane is only unloaded during daylight hours during the routine business week.  During this time period, the facility Emergency Brigade is populated and equipped to respond to an emergency involving pentane.  Flammable liquid firefigting and Hazardous Materiald Incident Management and Mitigation is part of the ongoing training of this team.

F)  FIVE YEAR HISTORY

This facility has not had a pentane accident in the past five years.

G)  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The CRYOVAC Reading facility believes in the prevention of a spill release and has installed an unloading facility to assist in accomplishing this goal along with a selected group of "A" level mechanics who are specially trained per the pentane unloading procedure to offload these tankers.  CRYOVAC does however believe that the unexpected can happen and therefore has taken several positive steps to suppress/mitigate a fire and/or spill should it occur, regardless of the remoteness of the possibility.  To insure the immediate suppression of a fire that could impact the tanker vessel, an A.F.F.F. firefighting foam system is installed over, under, and around the tanker truck or car and is heat activated.  The facility has a well-trained and motivated in-house response team and members of the team occupy the facility on a continuous basis, 7 days a week, 52 weeks per year.  The team tri-annually practices of flammable liquid firefighting and flammable gas firefighting on large demonstration fires at the Berks County Fire Traing Site, Reading, Pa.

The team has several documents that guide its actions during the emergencies that would involve pentane.  The material and the process fall under the RMP regulations, the stormwater regulations, RCRA PPC plans (preplans) and under the Clean Water Act with emphasis on "Slug unloading prevention of sanitary sewers".  All preplans have been sent to the local fire department who also visit or respond to the facility.  The particulars of the character of the pentane have

been sent to the County Emergency Management Agency and the Berks County L.E.P.C.  The local firefighting resources are three volunteer fire companies that provide protection to the Township on a mutual aid basis.



Robert Weaver
Environmental, Health, and Safety Supervisor


March 16, 2010
